list.item: Plans for a week end trip over the Smokies into No. Carolina.
Troubles of our handy man and his wife

div1.p: Dearest family It's 8:30 p.m. and I'm all ready for bed except to bid you a fond good night in a few scribbling lines. Jane's long letter came yesterday (Tuesday) mailed just a week ago today - Just think six days to get here. Am glad Mabel and Jo are finally settled and hope that they soon get into permanent quarters together. Give my love to Victoria & her mother when you meet them. Hope V. get along in school without any more sicknesses. The babies must be awfully sweet but Wein is too big for that appellation. Is he going to kindergarten? Hope so. Perhaps now you can rest on your oars a little both of you - you & Jane - for your letters have been exceedingly full of activity.

Though I wrote you Sunday night it seems as though there is so much to write again - not anything exciting as yet however - Monday I put in part of the day on my two drills for the coming fair but as so many youngsters are out again have almost decided to give up one of the older boys and girls having just the sunbonnet drill of twelve girls. They are dressed backwards - bonnets - shawls - aprons & skirts - but the top of the bonnet being thin they see perfectly - march how to go through maneuvers so that it will all look as tho tho they were doing it backwards. Then one of the girls in the neighborhood Lulu May McCarter who has been teaching & is getting ready to go away to school came over to school have me help her get a tele -
gram through to Knoxville. We fooled around here at the house unsuccessfully an hour or more & finally strolled with Emily up to the Huff's where we found some of them including Mrs. H. picking beans (Beans are planted in the corn fields you know & its now time to get them in since the corn fodder is pulled & also the season for making sorghum) we went over to their house where Mrs. Huff got the message through & then we sat in the big swing on the porch picked beans & ate apples until about six. It was dark before we finished supper and spent the evening quietly in the lamplight with my lessons & papers to correct. The weather is hot again & am glad to have thin dresses to wear. Tuesday was another busy
day. We girls decided to have a picnic up on the top of Pi Phi hill that night with Mr. Cresswell so after school Emily got the lunch ready as the rest of us were busy. Abbie & I with most of the girls in drill made sunbonnets from paper & thin white material. Aunt Lizzie, Mrs. Proffitt & Harrison came over to the sewing room also & got busy setting up the old loom which had been lying in its seperate parts ever since its return from the fair at Columbus this summer. Then as the little girl Arlena Maples who sweeps my room was absent I got the other two sweepers Maud Clabo and Ethel Carr to help me clean it up and then by that time left for the
house where we were soon assembled with 2 baskets - pail of water - frying pan - flashlight & headed up Pi Phi lane We turned directly off from it & went right up till we got to the top in about ten minutes. Here was a comparitively open space we spread out the couch cover which I insisted on bringing & Mr. C. made up a big bonfire. Pine branches burn so beautifully. In the course of time we started the coffee & spread out our frugal lunch - fried eggs - biscuit - weimis peanut butter - pimento cheese - chocolate bars & coffee. Our new Jersey cow provides us with lovely cream so the coffee is delicious & the butter too. In our conversation we
got to talking about our much postponed mountain trip and finally made up our minds to go this Friday! Start right after school with Dan & the hack drive as far as possible & then leave them. We will have just blankets & provisions with us so bad weather will put an end to our festivities. Mr. C. went up to Tom Camel's after school to find out if he'd take us & sure enough he will he and his two hounds! Then Emily & I went up to Lucrettie Reagan's after supper tonight and asked her mother to go with us as chaperone! If she doesn't go for she is not certain as Mr. Reagan thinks he needs her although she's wild to go with us we may go regardless we three
maidens & Mr. Cresswell with Tom Camel. Evelyn isn't back & probably wouldn't go any way Besides I warned her we'd celebrate in her absence!

Then besides all this excitement there has been more about Mary & Marshall. Monday night every thing was supposedly lovely he had withdrawn his suit for divorce & wanted her to go to Washington D.C. with him after withdrawing her cross suit. Well she went to Seveirville Tuesday to have her lawyer withdraw it & on her return here learned that Marshall had skipped out & left orders at the stores not to credit her with anything so
here she is deserted! I wrote a letter for her today to send her lawyer asking him about it Poor woman wonder what the next turn will be.
Must cease this scribble One more joyful item we will have to have our party for the school youngsters tomorrow night since we won't be here Friday also pack!
Will write again in a few days
With loads of love to each & all
